Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I clutched my phone, glancing at the clock. It was the last day of the quarter, and my manager’s voice echoed in my head: “We need three more sales, or we all lose our bonuses.” My headset buzzed with incoming calls, but I was standing in a long line at the polling station, waiting to vote. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss this election. Suddenly, an official called out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line.” My last name was Baker. The new line was longer, but the official’s instructions were clear. I hesitated, watching the original line inch forward. My phone vibrated—another potential customer. If I missed this call, I might lose a sale. If I ignored the official, I’d be breaking the rules. My heart pounded as I weighed the pressure from my boss against my duty as a voter. I could feel the eyes of the official and my manager—both expecting me to do the right thing for them. I stood frozen, torn between two worlds, unable to move.
